Are these errors or warnings?  Also, I assume that you saw them after restarting with the Update Manager.  Do they recur after you restart again without doing any updates?

This is related to bug 187202.

(In reply to comment #1)
> Are these errors or warnings?  Also, I assume that you saw them after
> restarting with the Update Manager.  Do they recur after you restart again
> without doing any updates?

Warnings. Yes, after restarting with the update manager. No, they do not reoccur when I restart again with no updates.

It is unclear to me whether we will be able to get rid of these warnings.  I can only ever reproduce them with an Update Manager restart, which makes me suspcious for the reasons pointed out on bug 187202 and because of bug 107280.  Also, these warnings have not been attributed to any bad behavior. Still, it will be annoying to have them in everyone's log so I will continue investigating.

If this isn't simply update-based start weirdness, there is a very good chance that this was fixed by removing the remaining extension point read that we were doing on start(..), via fixes for bug 189054.  I'll monitor to see the effects.
It looks like this can still occur after the first Update Manager based install.  Still no bad effects noticed or reported.  We can investigate further in the 3.0 cycle.
Reopening.

See bug 191193 comment 4 for the reason a similar error was happening for JDT UI.  This error does not have fatel side effects but it does cause two threads to suspend for 5 seconds while waiting for the framework to break the deadlock caused by the VM holding a classloader lock.

Thanks for the pointer Thomas!  I have tried to move as much as possible out of the start() method of that plug-in.  Is the only approach to addressing this to move even more out or to add the SynchronousBundleListener?  Not sure I can do the latter because of the way that we currently need to initialize extension points.  

Also, is it 'normal' that this would only happen on the first restart after an Update Manager install, and not on subsequent restarts?

What bundle is this in now.  I have not looked at the new mylyn code to make a recommendation.  Note that this error is very much timing related.  I imagine the timing is a little different after the an initialization from a clean configuration or after bundles have been installed for the first time.  You are probably just lucky that this is not consistently reproduced on cached restarts.

Thanks Thomas, it would be great if you could spot any telltales of a problem that we could address or postpone until later in the startup.  Note that Mylyn currently has a requirement to read XML that's written by connectors (e.g. Bugzilla) before it can show editors for the corresponding tasks/bugs (need to be done before the workbench starts restoring editors).  Makes sense that the caching would affect the timing.  To check I tried to reproduce running with -clean and didn't see it on normal (non-update restart) but Vista tends to make re-launches faster due to its own caching and prefetching.  

I'm attaching the TasksUiPlugin file which has the problematic start(..) method, but here is the main project set for Mylyn:

  http://www.eclipse.org/mylyn/doc/dev/mylyn.psf

There are two warnings in the log, both with the same stack trace.  The messages are:

Hi,

I have been experiencing the problem as well and believe can contribute some debugging pointers from a user perspective:

1) To reproduce

- Download the latest europa RCP edition (e.g. eclipse-rcp-europa-fall-win32.zip).
- Start Eclipse. The problem does not occur.
- Switch to the Plug-in Development perspective.
- Exit Eclipse while the other (not the "Java") perspective is active.
- Restart Eclipse.
- The problem occurs.

The freeze occurs depending on the initial workbench perspective. There seems to be some nastiness among Mylyn and certain perspectives during startup. I have found that the PDE and Debug perspectives cause the problems, whereas the Java and Team Synchronization perspectives don't.

2) Workaround

- Go to Window->Preferences->General.
- Select "Startup and shutdown".
- Disable the "Mylyn Tasks UI".

With Mylyn inactive during startup, you avoid the problem.

I have additional info.

I noticed that the Team synchronization and Java perspective have something related to Mylyn in common: the both have a view contributed by Mylyn in their default layout. The Java perspective shows the "Task List" by default, whereas the Team-sync shows the "Task Repositories".

To test whether this is a contributing factor, I added the "Task List" view to the PDE perspective and re-started eclipse. Indeed, the problem does not occur in that case.

Hope this helps.

We are in the process of evaluating whether all the new duplicates of this are a related to the Platform 3.3.1 PergGen problem, since several of the stack traces contained the these warnings in conjunction with PermGen errors.

We've found a way to almost reliably reproduce the warnings:
* Install Fall Update EPP/JEE, launch, do not use or start any Mylyn UI or views
* Install some trivial update and restart
* Note errors in log

Steffen and I have outlined approaches for addressing this without breaking API by trying to offload startup that's currently asynchronous (but apparently blocking nad causing the warnings in some scenarios) into separate jobs.  Investigating futher...

(In reply to comment #30)
> We've found a way to almost reliably reproduce the warnings:
This is only a semi-reliable way to reproduce.  The warnings are still very intermittent, but are definitely more to come up likely if the restart is caused by an update.

Steffen: fyi, I'm nearly done with a solution to this.  It goes along the lines of our last discussion.

This will be a pretty huge change which means that the UI Bridge plug-ins that add focused UI facilities will have a separate lazy load lifecycle that does not get started until there is a context activation.  These plug-ins will still be able to do their usual extension point contributions (e.g. Java stack trace URL detector) and start without initializing their own extension points.  Once something triggers the activation of a task context happens then the focused UI facilities load themselves.  The idea up until now was that it was OK for those facilities to load themselves as long as they didn't do anything if no task was active.  But this was still causing too much activation on startup, a significant portion of which was happening synchronously even though it was in asyncExecs (due to the object locks that we found as per Thomas Watson's comments on bug 191193).  Thankfully all of the trickiness is encapsulated by a new AbstractContextUiPlugin (name is tentative), which extends AbstractUIPlugin.

Thanks Willian.  It looks like a Platform decorator could still trigger the problematic loading.  I have removed the most likely case to have caused this.  When you next update (weekly build coming this evening) please see if you get this again.  If so, please attach your entire configuration (Help -> About Eclipse SDK -> Configuration Details) and let me know whether you are starting with or without a task active, and whether the results differ.
It appears to be fixed in I20071128-2200. But I'll keep an eye on this.
Thanks for confirming Willian.  Please post if you see anything of this sort again.  If there are any remaining startup concurrencies they should be pretty straightforward to work out.
